summary_md: Using Kruskal’s integral identity and a sparse threshold graph H(t) we proved MST_log(π) ≤ Reg_log(π) for the L∞ norm; norm equivalence lifts this to MST_log^N(π) ≤ C_N·Reg_log(π) for any fixed norm. A residue-class (mod-m, e.g. parity) permutation family gives MST_log=Θ(n) but Reg_log=Θ(n log n), so Reg_log/MST_log=Θ(log n) and no universal constant reverses the inequality. A trivial per-edge lower bound on MST yields Reg_log(π) ≤ (log(1+n)/c_N)·MST_log^N(π), so the worst-case multiplicative gap is Θ(log n) and is tight. (Citations: Research Notes; Current Proofs.)
one_line_summary: MST_log ≤ C·Reg_log; reverse fails — worst-case gap Θ(log n).
highlights: Kruskal-integral + sparse H(t) gives MST_log^{∞}(π) ≤ ∑_{i} log(1+min(Δ_i,t_i)) ≤ Reg_log(π).
For any fixed norm N, MST_log^N(π) ≤ C_N·Reg_log(π) via norm-lifting (explicit C_N from operator-norm bound).
Residue-class (mod-m) permutations (parity m=2) achieve MST_log=Θ(n) and Reg_log=Θ(n log n), so Reg_log/MST_log=Θ(log n).
Universal reverse bound: Reg_log(π) ≤ (log(1+n)/c_N)·MST_log^N(π) with explicit c_N for L∞, L2, L1 (log2, log(1+√2), log3).
Hence the worst-case multiplicative gap between the measures is Θ(log n), and this factor is tight.
next_questions: Optimize/compute best constants C_N and c_N for common norms (L1,L2,L∞).
Determine leading constants/asymptotics of E[MST_log] and E[Reg_log] for a uniform random permutation.
Search for (or prove impossibility of) permutation families with separation > Θ(log n).
